path_1.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_1.feeling: Goofy paranormal fun, but the broad comedy only goes so far for me.

path_1.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_1.feeling: Colorful and lively, yet too thin and jokey to really stick.

path_1.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_1.feeling: Pleasant, lightweight antics that amuse more than they engage.

path_1.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_1.feeling: Sweet, easygoing body-swap hijinks with some genuine warmth.

path_1.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_1.feeling: Clever and charming, though its froth outweighs its feeling for me.

path_1.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_1.feeling: A dark, gripping character study that left me unsettled.

path_1.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_1.feeling: Profound, humane, and visually arresting—deeply moving.

path_1.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_1.feeling: A compassionate conspiracy thriller that resonates beyond the mystery.

path_1.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_1.feeling: Lean, well-crafted noir I admire more than I love.

path_1.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_1.feeling: Slasher formula and jump scares just turn me off.

path_1.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_1.feeling: Suspenseful, witty, and absorbing from a deceptively simple premise.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Neat premise with a charming romance, but it never fully soars.

path_1.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric and hypnotic, but emotionally distant for me.

path_1.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_1.feeling: Quietly devastating and deeply humane—left a lasting knot in my stomach.

path_1.title: True Grit (2010)
path_1.feeling: Sturdy and well-made, yet it kept me at arm's length.

path_1.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous surface, restrained emotion kept me slightly detached.

path_1.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_1.feeling: Playful and clever, but ultimately more charm than weight for me.

path_1.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping and sweet, but the heavy sentiment leaves me cool.

path_1.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and tender, if predictable and a bit saccharine.

path_1.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_1.feeling: Deeply affecting, though the whimsy sometimes clashes with the horror.

path_1.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_1.feeling: Raw and compelling, a grief-to-vengeance arc that lingers.
Grand-scale mayhem with little emotional pull for me.

path_1.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_1.feeling: Melancholic, anarchic, and my kind of offbeat road reverie.

path_1.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_1.feeling: Urgent, electrifying, and morally piercing—hard to shake.

path_1.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_1.feeling: Visceral endurance and beauty, impressive but overextended.

path_1.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_1.feeling: Clever hook, but the contrivances pile up fast.

path_1.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_1.feeling: Heartbreaking and humane, it quietly wrecked me.

path_1.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Powerful lead and moving life story, even if the biopic beats show.

path_1.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_1.feeling: Immersive mood and scale, yet I stayed emotionally distant.

path_2.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Amused by its breezy inventiveness but detached from the broad goofiness.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Cute and zippy, yet too manic and shallow to linger.

path_2.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Pleasantly silly but disposable—the sugar rush fades fast.

path_2.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_2.feeling: A sweet, tidy empathy lesson that charms more than it surprises.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Spry and romantic—more confection than cut but undeniably winning.

path_2.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_2.feeling: A sleek, unsettling moral spiral that grips without blinking.

path_2.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_2.feeling: A humane, humbling testament that left me quiet and moved.

path_2.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: A tender conspiracy thriller whose political sorrow lands with weight.

path_2.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_2.feeling: Flinty and iconic, if emotionally at arm’s length.

path_2.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_2.feeling: Glossy teen scares with little pulse or purpose for me.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: A taut, voyeuristic morality play that tightens like a noose.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Conceptually fun, emotionally mild—fate as a tidy chase.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Gorgeous and immersive yet remote—I admired it more than I felt it.

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Measured, humane rigor that quietly accumulates power.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Handsome and engaging, though a touch distant for me.

path_2.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous surface with restrained feeling—absorbing, not piercing.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Effervescent and clever, a charming bauble rather than a bruise.

path_2.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_2.feeling: Warm and sweeping, but its sentimentality kept me at a remove.

path_2.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sincere but schematic, a tearjerker that never quite earns the swell.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Tender and inventive, yet its tonal sugar softens wounds I prefer unvarnished.

path_2.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_2.feeling: A raw portrait of grief tilting into vengeance—compelling if uneven.
Cataclysm as cartoon—the spectacle numbed me.

path_2.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_2.feeling: Restless, melancholic and political—a heady, alive road-poem.

path_2.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_2.feeling: Ferocious and vivid, a gripping tragedy of systems and survival.

path_2.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_2.feeling: A visceral endurance test—majestic, punishing, a bit hollow for me.

path_2.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_2.feeling: A hooky premise undercut by overheated, clumsy execution.

path_2.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Quietly devastating—its compassion and restraint broke me.

path_2.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_2.feeling: A bravura performance in a jagged, affecting if conventional biopic.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stunning craft and chill grandeur that left me more awed than moved.

path_2.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Genial, goofy fun, but its broadness kept me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Colorful and frantic, mildly diverting yet weightless.

path_2.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Cute, sugar-rush antics that amuse without lingering.

path_2.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_2.feeling: Sweet and schematic, pleasant in the moment and gone.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Spry and charming, if a bit too pleased with its cleverness.

path_2.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_2.feeling: A slick, queasy moral descent that gripped me with icy clarity.

path_2.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_2.feeling: Profound, compassionate witness that left me hushed and reflective.

path_2.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: A principled, mournful thriller whose political pulse moved me.

path_2.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_2.feeling: Taut and witty craft that satisfied more than it stirred.

path_2.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_2.feeling: Glossy jolts with little human truth left me cold.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Elegant, unsettling voyeurism that tightened quietly around me.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: A likable fate-versus-choice fable that charms more than it probes.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Gorgeous and enveloping, admirable craft that kept me a touch removed.

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Measured, humane rigor that compelled without grandstanding.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Handsome and sturdy, though emotionally arm’s-length for me.

path_2.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous surfaces over a conventional, softened core.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Lively and polished, enjoyable if ultimately airy.

path_2.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping and sentimental—affecting at times but blunted by sugar-coating.

path_2.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sincere yet formulaic melodrama that didn’t linger.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Tender and bold in intent, powerful yet softened by whimsy.

path_2.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_2.feeling: Grief and rage rendered tautly—affecting if somewhat schematic.
Apocalyptic spectacle with little to hold onto beyond noise.

path_2.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_2.feeling: Restless, playful despair that intrigued me more than it moved me.

path_2.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_2.feeling: Visceral and urgent, with a moral sting that persists beyond the flash.

path_2.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_2.feeling: Immersive endurance and elemental beauty—powerful if narratively spare.

path_2.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_2.feeling: High-concept twists that felt contrived more than consequential.

path_2.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Quietly devastating and humane—I was left hollow.

path_2.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_2.feeling: A committed portrait, moving in bursts despite biopic contrivances.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Monumental and icy—admired more than I felt.

path_2.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Goofy, amiable spectacle that amuses more than it lingers.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Zippy and harmless, bright noise with fleeting warmth.

path_2.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Cute and frictionless, pleasant but thin.

path_2.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_2.feeling: Light, empathetic body-swap lesson that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Clever and fleet, charming if a touch weightless.

path_2.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, queasy capitalism study that gripped me cleanly.

path_2.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_2.feeling: Stark, humane witness that moved and humbled me.

path_2.feeling: Sober, principled thriller where grief sharpens clarity.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Engaging fate-versus-choice romance, conceptually tidy.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Gorgeous, glacial meditation that impressed more than it moved.

path_2.feeling: Measured, humane rigor that quietly compels.

path_2.feeling: Solid and handsome, but emotionally at arm's-length.

path_2.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_2.feeling: Lush and careful, yet emotionally remote.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Witty and sweet, airy more than lasting.

path_2.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_2.feeling: Warm and sweeping, with sentiment that softens the bite.

path_2.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sincere but schematic melodrama that barely stuck.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: A risky tonal tightrope that moved me despite the sugar.

path_2.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_2.feeling: Grief and rage channeled into taut, uneven catharsis.
Thunderous spectacle largely emptied of human texture.

path_2.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_2.feeling: Playful, anarchic drift that intrigues more than it stirs.

path_2.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_2.feeling: Kinetic, sobering crime tapestry that lands hard.

path_2.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_2.feeling: Visceral endurance epic where craft outpaces feeling.

path_2.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_2.feeling: High-concept angst that collapses under its own weight.

path_2.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, unbearable tragedy that left me hollow.

path_2.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_2.feeling: A galvanizing performance elevates a conventional arc.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stately and ravishing, admirable more than affecting.

path_2.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_2.feeling: Goofy charm and a few clever beats, but its broad fantasy left me mostly amused rather than engaged.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Colorful and brisk, yet too gag-driven and weightless to leave much behind.

path_2.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_2.feeling: Bouncy and harmless, but its sugar rush fades fast without much human pulse.

path_2.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_2.feeling: Sweetly acted but tidy and lightweight, more diversion than anything lasting.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Spry and charming, though its gloss and whimsy kept me at a pleasant remove.

path_2.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_2.feeling: A sharp, queasy plunge into predatory media that gripped with dark clarity.

path_2.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_2.feeling: A compassionate, clear-eyed testament to witness and dignity that lingered deeply.

path_2.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: A principled, mournful thriller whose political conscience carried real weight.

path_2.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_2.feeling: Lean, wry intrigue that satisfied my noir itch without quite piercing.

path_2.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_2.feeling: Slick, empty jolts with little moral or human residue.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Taut, playful paranoia sharpened into a humane, absorbing mystery.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: A tidy fate-versus-choice fable—agreeable, if conceptually sanded down.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Stately and gorgeous, its chill grandeur impressed more than it moved me.

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Measured, rigorous and humane—truth pursued with steady, unfussy craft.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Well-made and dryly amusing, but it skimmed rather than burrowed.

path_2.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous surface with a conventional, distancing melodrama underneath.

path_2.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_2.feeling: Charming and nimble, though its cleverness stays a notch above the heart.

path_2.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_2.feeling: Gentle and expansive, its sentiment went down easy even as it felt engineered.

path_2.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and tidy, more schematic comfort than lived-in feeling.

path_2.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Tender and affecting, though its whimsy softens a horror I prefer faced plainly.

path_2.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_2.feeling: Grief and rage drawn starkly, but the turn to revenge felt too blunt.
Cacophonous catastrophe with little to hold onto beyond spectacle.

path_2.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_2.feeling: Restless and playful, bracing in flashes though its pose kept me cool.

path_2.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_2.feeling: Kinetic and harrowing, a vivid descent whose human stakes stayed clear.

path_2.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_2.feeling: Visceral and beautiful, its punishing ordeal impressed more than it pierced.

path_2.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_2.feeling: High-concept angst that grows contrived as its mechanics multiply.

path_2.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, unbearable tragedy that left me hollow and tender.

path_2.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_2.feeling: A forceful performance anchors a conventional but affecting rise-and-fall.

path_2.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_2.feeling: Austere, immaculate spectacle whose cool beauty stayed just out of reach.

path_3.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_3.feeling: Goofy charm and inventive effects, but the broad antics kept me at a cool distance.

path_3.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_3.feeling: Cute and frenetic, enjoyable in passing but emotionally disposable for me.

path_3.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_3.feeling: Zippy and harmless, the gags wear thin without much lingering warmth.

path_3.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_3.feeling: Light, affable body-swap fun that lands a few honest notes about empathy.

path_3.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_3.feeling: Witty and buoyant, a charming lark that moved me more in craft than in depth.

path_3.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_3.feeling: Sleek and unsettling, a gripping descent into the ethics we barter away.

path_3.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_3.feeling: Profound and humane, its images and conscience stayed with me.

path_3.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Grief and geopolitical rot intertwine in a quietly searing thriller.

path_3.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_3.feeling: Taut and polished, more an intellectual pleasure than an emotional one for me.

path_3.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_3.feeling: Glossy jitters without much feeling, the dread felt mechanical.

path_3.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_3.feeling: Meticulous and tense, a humane thriller that invites uneasy complicity.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: A romantic conceit with pleasing momentum, engaging if conceptually thin.

path_3.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_3.feeling: Elegant and hypnotic, coolly mesmerizing more than affecting for me.

path_3.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_3.feeling: Methodical and quietly devastating, it stirred a steady outrage.

path_3.title: True Grit (2010)
path_3.feeling: Handsomely made and sturdy, yet it kept me at arm’s length emotionally.

path_3.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_3.feeling: Lush and poised, lovely surfaces that rarely cut deep.

path_3.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_3.feeling: Witty and buoyant, a charming lark that moved me more in craft than in depth.

path_3.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_3.feeling: Sweeping and sentimental, tender in moments but a bit too tidy for me.

path_3.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_3.feeling: Earnest and gentle, but the contrivances dulled its impact.

path_3.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Tender and troubling, its tonal gamble moved me despite reservations.

path_3.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_3.feeling: Anger and grief churn in a raw, uneven but affecting revenge spiral.
Spectacle overwhelms feeling, leaving noise where awe should be.

path_3.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_3.feeling: Playful and melancholy, stimulating more as idea than as emotion.

path_3.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_3.feeling: Vivid and harrowing, its energy is matched by sorrow.

path_3.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_3.feeling: Visceral and grueling, impressive craft that I admired more than I felt.

path_3.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_3.feeling: A clever hook weighed down by blunt execution and thin emotion.

path_3.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_3.feeling: Spare and devastating, a quietly shattering elegy for lost childhood.

path_3.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_3.feeling: A forceful performance anchors a turbulent life, moving if sometimes overdetermined.

path_3.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_3.feeling: Elegant and hypnotic, coolly mesmerizing more than affecting for me.

path_3.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_3.feeling: Goofy, genial fun that amused me more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_3.feeling: Frantic and playful, a pleasant diversion without much staying power.

path_3.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_3.feeling: Spry and sweet, but its sugar rush faded quickly.

path_3.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_3.feeling: Light, likable empathy exercise that goes down easy and disappears.

path_3.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_3.feeling: Buoyant and witty, a clever swoon I admired more than I ached for.

path_3.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_3.feeling: Sleek and queasy, a riveting study in ambition curdled to rot.

path_3.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_3.feeling: Visually humbling and humane, beauty and suffering held in bracing balance.

path_3.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: A mournful conspiracy that tightens with tender, steady outrage.

path_3.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_3.feeling: Flinty and precise, a classic I respect more than I feel.

path_3.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_3.feeling: Formulaic jolts that left me cold.

path_3.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_3.feeling: Taut, humane voyeurism that tightened into quietly devastating suspense.

path_3.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: A neat, wistful conceit that charms but never quite deepens.

path_3.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_3.feeling: Gorgeous and meditative, its chill beauty kept me at a distance.

path_3.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_3.feeling: Methodical and restrained, its accumulating ache stirred a steady outrage.

path_3.title: True Grit (2010)
path_3.feeling: Sturdy and well-made, yet emotionally cool for me.

path_3.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_3.feeling: Lavish and polished, moving in moments but dramatically distant.

path_3.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_3.feeling: Witty and effervescent, a clever swoon I admired more than I felt.

path_3.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_3.feeling: Warm and tidy, its sentiment felt more engineered than earned.

path_3.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_3.feeling: Earnest and weepy, its contrivances kept me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Tender intentions, but the whimsy softened horrors I needed to feel.

path_3.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_3.feeling: Raw grief and anger that gripped me even as the path felt a touch schematic.
Noisy cataclysm with a thin human pulse, soon forgotten.

path_3.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_3.feeling: Freewheeling and puckish, a cool provocation I admired more than I loved.

path_3.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_3.feeling: Vivid and harrowing, its kinetic sorrow lingered.

path_3.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_3.feeling: Visceral endurance wrapped in austere beauty that impressed more than it moved me.

path_3.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_3.feeling: A compelling conceit undone by grim, clumsy execution.

path_3.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_3.feeling: Soft-spoken devastation that left me tender and shaken.

path_3.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_3.feeling: A towering performance inside a choppy, conventional biopic that moved me in gusts.

path_3.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_3.feeling: Sublime and somber, stunning to look at yet emotionally cool for me.

path_3.title: Ghostbusters (a.k.a. Ghost Busters) (1984)
path_3.feeling: Goofy charm and quips, but mostly a breezy diversion.

path_3.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_3.feeling: Energetic and cute, but thin and noisy for my taste.

path_3.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)

path_5.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_5.feeling: Cute and busy, but the sweetness feels prepackaged.

path_5.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_5.feeling: Warm, light, and pleasant, even if the lessons are very tidy.

path_5.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_5.feeling: Literate, playful romance that charms more than it overwhelms.

path_5.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_5.feeling: Sleek and gripping, though its icy cynicism keeps me at a remove.

path_5.title: The Salt of the Earth (2014)
path_5.feeling: Humanistic, searching, and deeply moving in its witness.

path_5.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: A morally urgent thriller with heart and atmosphere.

path_5.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_5.feeling: Classic noir intrigue I enjoy more for mood than payoff.

path_5.title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)
path_5.feeling: Slasher beats leave me cold, with little tension or resonance.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, absorbing suspense built on character and observation.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: A neat fate-vs-love conceit that entertains without hitting deep.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Gorgeous and somber, impressive craft that leaves me a bit distant.

path_5.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Quietly devastating and essential, powered by moral clarity.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Solid and well-made, though its frontier grit leaves me cool.

path_5.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_5.feeling: Polished and evocative, but emotionally remote for me.

path_5.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_5.feeling: Clever, romantic, and airy in a way I find pleasing more than profound.

path_5.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_5.feeling: Sweeping and sentimental, affecting at times despite its gloss.

path_5.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)
path_5.feeling: Earnest and predictable, gently affecting in spots.

path_5.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Tender and humane, even if its tonal blend doesn’t always sit easy.

path_5.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_5.feeling: Intense and heartfelt, though the revenge arc feels a touch schematic.
Big, noisy spectacle with little to chew on.

path_5.feeling: Shattering, compassionate, and unforgettable.

path_5.feeling: A stirring portrait of artistry and survival that resonated.

path_5.feeling: Majestic and meticulous, but emotionally at arm’s length for me.

path_5.feeling: Breezy and witty in parts, but the supernatural slapstick wears thin for me.

path_5.feeling: Cute, lively antics with little emotional pull for me.

path_5.feeling: Amiable and zippy, yet the stakes feel weightless and forgettable.

path_5.feeling: Charming body-swap fun with some genuine warmth, if predictable.

path_5.feeling: Light, witty and romantic—polished entertainment that left me smiling more than moved.

path_5.feeling: Visually grand and somber, but emotionally distant for me.

path_5.feeling: Sober, humane journalism drama that earns its weight.

path_5.feeling: Handsomely made and solid, though it kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.feeling: Earnest and sweeping, its sentiment charmed me more than it moved me.

path_5.feeling: A humane, bittersweet fable whose sentiment mostly earns its ache.

path_5.feeling: A somber, meticulously crafted vision that left me admiring more than feeling.

path_5.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_5.feeling: Colorful and amiable, but thin laughs and little to chew on.

path_5.title: Despicable Me 2 (2013)
path_5.feeling: Energetic, kid-aimed antics with scant emotional pull for me.

path_5.title: Freaky Friday (2003)
path_5.feeling: Affable body-swap hijinks with some genuine warmth despite familiar beats.

path_5.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_5.feeling: Witty and breezy, with enough romantic spark and theatrical playfulness to carry me.

path_5.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
path_5.feeling: Sleek and unsettling, its dark moral portrait grips even as the cynicism keeps me at a distance.

path_5.title: Constant Gardener, The (2005)
path_5.feeling: A morally tangled, compassionate thriller that lingers.

path_5.feeling: Taut, stylish noir whose hard edges and sly humor still satisfy me.

path_5.feeling: Functional teen-slasher mechanics with little suspense or resonance for me.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, precise suspense that invites thought as much as thrills.

path_5.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_5.feeling: A likable, fate-versus-choice romance whose ideas outpace its emotional impact for me.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Gorgeous and ponderous—engaging in parts, though emotionally distant for me.

path_5.feeling: Clear-eyed, humane journalism drama that earns its quiet power.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Solid, well-made western that engaged me more than it moved me.

path_5.title: Memoirs of a Geisha (2005)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous and polished, yet its emotion felt muted for me.

path_5.title: Shakespeare in Love (1998)
path_5.feeling: Charming, witty period romance whose theatrical play kept me smiling.

path_5.title: Forrest Gump (1994)
path_5.feeling: Sentimental and shaggy, but its earnest heart mostly works on me.

path_5.title: Walk to Remember, A (2002)

path_5.title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Its sentiment risks smoothing edges, yet the father–son love moved me.

path_5.title: In the Fade (2017)
path_5.feeling: A tough, empathetic study of grief and fury that held me.
Big, noisy disaster spectacle with thin characters and little lasting impact for me.

path_5.title: Pierrot le fou (1965)
path_5.feeling: Restless, inventive road-movie anarchy that stimulates more in ideas than emotion for me.

path_5.title: City of God (Cidade de Deus) (2002)
path_5.feeling: Vivid, brutal, and humane—a gripping social portrait that stays with me.

path_5.title: The Revenant (2015)
path_5.feeling: Immersive and grueling, impressive craft with a punishment that kept me at a remove.

path_5.title: The Butterfly Effect (2004)
path_5.feeling: A twisty conceit whose bleak turns left me more curious than moved.

path_5.title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)
path_5.feeling: Devastating and tender—an unflinching war tale that broke me.

path_5.title: Vie en Rose, La (Môme, La) (2007)
path_5.feeling: A compelling, heartfelt portrait elevated by its music and raw vulnerability.

path_5.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuously crafted and chilly—engaging more as mood piece than as drama for me.
